hero.oneLiner: An automated drink dispensing machine that pours measured drinks or shots, with manual control and a web interface to adjust output.

context.text: Pouring consistent drinks is unreliable. Free-pouring varies by person, speed, and attention, especially in social settings. I wanted a system that could dispense repeatable quantities on demand, work hands-free when needed, and still allow manual control. The constraint was to keep it simple, affordable, and suitable for DIY deployment rather than a commercial bar system.

bullets: Automated liquid pumping and dispensing mechanism
Manual dispense input for quick pours
Web-based UI to configure pour quantity and modes
Calibrated flow control logic for repeatable output

decisions.decision: Web UI control vs physical-only controls
decisions.why: Allowed quick reconfiguration of pour volumes without rebuilding hardware.
decisions.tradeoff: Required networking and basic frontend work.

decisions.decision: Manual override mode vs fully automated system
decisions.why: Preserved usability during network failure or casual use.

worked: Calibration-based pours stayed consistent across repeated use.
Web UI made adjusting drink sizes fast and intuitive.
Manual mode ensured the system remained usable at all times.
didnt: Different liquid viscosities affected accuracy more than expected.

outcome.text: SoloPump became a reliable automated drink dispensing system capable of consistent pours in both manual and automated modes. It demonstrated how low-cost electronics and simple control logic can replace skill-based tasks with repeatable outcomes.

reflection.text: This project clarified how software control and calibration can replace human skill in repeatable physical tasks without over-engineering the system.
